title: Colette Magny
text:
Colette Magny (31 October 1926 – 12 June 1997) was a French singer and songwriter. A charismatic performer who did not record until her thirties, her work encompassed <a href="blues">blues</a>, <a href="jazz">jazz</a>, <a href="protest%20song">protest song</a>s, <a href="experimental%20music">experimental music</a> and <a href="spoken%20word">spoken word</a> recordings.
Life and career.
She was born in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>, and from 1948 worked as a secretary and <a href="translator">translator</a> for the <a href="Organisation%20for%20Economic%20Co-operation%20and%20Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a> (OECD). Fluent in <a href="English%20language">English</a>, she became a fan of American <a href="blues">blues</a> and <a href="jazz">jazz</a> singers such as <a href="Bessie%20Smith">Bessie Smith</a> and <a href="Ella%20Fitzgerald">Ella Fitzgerald</a>, and was taught <a href="guitar">guitar</a> by jazz musician <a href="Claude%20Luter">Claude Luter</a>. She also started writing songs. Her mother took up acting in the 1950s, and Colette began singing her own songs and <a href="blues%20standard">blues standard</a>s in Paris clubs. She made her first recordings in 1958, on an album by <a href="trumpet">trumpet</a>er and bandleader <a href="Gilles%20Thibaut">Gilles Thibaut</a>, "Des classiques du jazz".
After appearing at the Contrescarpe <a href="cabaret">cabaret</a> in 1962, she was discovered by the singer <a href="Mireille%20Hartuch">Mireille Hartuch</a>, who featured her on her TV show "Le Petit Conservatoire de la Chanson". She received rave reviews, and gave up her full-time job for a musical career. She signed with <a href="CBS%20Records%20International">CBS Records</a>, and her first single, the self-penned "Melocoton" ("Peach"), which featured <a href="Mickey%20Baker">Mickey Baker</a> on guitar as did many of her later recordings, became a hit in France in 1963. Her first album, self-titled but sometimes known as "Les Tuileries", also featured her musical treatments of poems by <a href="Victor%20Hugo">Victor Hugo</a>, <a href="Rimbaud">Rimbaud</a>, <a href="Rilke">Rilke</a> and <a href="Louis%20Aragon">Louis Aragon</a>, as well as blues classics including "<a href="St.%20James%20Infirmary%20Blues">Saint James Infirmary</a>" and Bessie Smith's "Any Woman's Blues". Her second album, the experimental ""Avec" poème" (1966), released on the record label established by <a href="Marcel%20Mouloudji">Marcel Mouloudji</a>, contained both spoken and sung texts over <a href="electroacoustic%20music">electroacoustic music</a> and "<a href="musique%20concr%C3%A8te">musique concrète</a>" by the <a href="Surrealist">Surrealist</a>-influenced composer <a href="Andr%C3%A9%20Almur%C3%B3">André Almuró</a>.
Magny became increasingly supportive of political activism. Her song "Le mal du vivre" was banned by <a href="ORTF">ORTF</a>, the state broadcasting network, and marked her out as France's first <a href="protest%20singer">protest singer</a>. Her recordings were issued by <a href="Le%20Chant%20du%20Monde">Le Chant du Monde</a>. Her next album, also self-titled, featured her songs "Vietnam 67" and "Viva Cuba", together with one celebrating a strike of port workers, as well as further settings of poems and <a href="metaphysical">metaphysical</a> texts. During the events and riots of <a href="May%2068">May 68</a>, she actively supported students and workers at <a href="sit-in">sit-in</a>s and through <a href="benefit%20concert">benefit concert</a>s. She wrote the song "Les militants" for the protesters, and later also issued a <a href="spoken%20word">spoken word</a> album, "Magny 68/69".
She produced three albums in the early 1970s – "Feu et rythme" (1970), which won the <a href="Grand%20Prix%20du%20Disque">Grand Prix du Disque</a> from the <a href="Acad%C3%A9mie%20Charles%20Cros">Académie Charles Cros</a>; "Répression" (1972), which concerned <a href="censorship">censorship</a> and was supportive of the <a href="Black%20Panther%20Party">Black Panther</a> movement; and "Transit" (1975), which she recorded with <a href="free%20jazz">free jazz</a> performers including saxophonist <a href="Maurice%20Merle">Maurice Merle</a>. Her 1977 album "Visage-Village" was recorded with the <a href="rock%20music">rock group</a> Dharma and <a href="accordion">accordion</a>ist Lino Leonardi. According to writer Benoît Houzé, "throughout her experiments, Magny always kept an artistic generosity which clearly binds most of her songs, as 'avant-gardist' as they can be, to the tradition of French "<a href="Chanson%23Modern%20chanson">chanson populaire</a>"."
Her 1979 album "Je Veux Chaanter" was recorded with, and included songs written by, children with mental disabilities in the Institut médico-pédagogique at <a href="Fontenoy-le-Ch%C3%A2teau">Fontenoy-le-Château</a>, and was performed partly with home-made instruments. In 1980, she released two single-sided spoken word albums, one of poems by <a href="Antonin%20Artaud">Antonin Artaud</a> and the other of text by the Swiss artist <a href="Sylvie%20Duval">Sylvie Duval</a>. Magny moved to live near <a href="Aveyron">Aveyron</a> in south-west France, and her recordings became more mellow in tone, her 1983 album "Chansons pour Titine" even including <a href="Cole%20Porter">Cole Porter</a>'s "<a href="My%20Heart%20Belongs%20to%20Daddy">My Heart Belongs to Daddy</a>". Her final album, "Kevork" (1989), included a song in praise of the <a href="turkey%20%28bird%29">turkey</a>, a bird which, once released from domestication, can revert to its wild state.
Magny suffered from health problems including <a href="obesity">obesity</a> and, in later years, a spinal disease that confined her to a bed or wheelchair. She died in 1997, aged 70.
Biography.
A biography by Sylvie Vadureau, "Colette Magny, Citoyenne - Blues", was published in 2017.
